content.description: One crux may be gaining a small ledge and a second may be surpassing the dihedral to reach the anchors. This route is hard for the grade with moves that are not intuitive.
content.location: Coming down the access trail of whippoorwill, it's on the right side. It's the left most bolted line, left of Pat-Agonia and right of Mythos.

climbs.name: Where have All the Cowboys Gone?

content.description: Trad placement only lasts for ~25 feet then you hit the bolt and after that its pretty much a ladder. If you're there with some nuts, you might as well do it.
content.protection: Stoppers and cams up to #1. After first bolt, a horizontal placement. Followed by 1 more bolt and then two top anchors.
content.location: Two over to the left of latch key kid, right of corner route flight of the kiwi. Old guide says it should be one over but someone bolted a new route to left of it.

content.description: Nice holds up good quality rock. Very comfortable lead with nice clip stances.
content.location: On obvious arete to the right of Logos and Straight outta lockmont

content.description:
Stick clip and then boulder off the ground to reach an obvious jug system left of the second bolt. Proceed rightwards

up the pristine left facing ramp, gastoning and sidepulling with smeary feet. Clip, then lunge and keep your wits about you

to escape the white rock section.

The difficulty lets up as you head towards the anchors, but tread carefully - the rock quality decreases as well.
content.location: When facing the access gully, it's on climber's left, next to the blunt arete of Wafer (12a). Look for an obvious ramp near the second bolt.

content.description: Climb the arete.  The moves to the second bolt are very bouldery.  The crux is reaching the 3rd bolt.  Here you will find a very reachy technical move or a cool dyno to reach a really positve hold.  Climbing after this is significantly easier to the shuts.
content.location: This is the first arete that you will encounter as you descend down to the cliff.  This is also the last route to be accessed during high water.

content.description: Starts either from the ground in a dirty corner that's underwater much of the year, or from a ledge directly right. For full value, pull a juggy roof move from the ground, then plug your first piece. Or traverse in from the ledge on the right. Great holds and a jam or two will get you to a 2 bolt anchor with rings.
content.protection: Any cams from #2 to #.3 and set of nuts will easily get you through this one. Bolted anchor.
content.location: Between Wendy's Jugs and Ching Chang Chong.  If you get to the taller wall that has Latchkey Kids on it, you've gone too far.

content.description:
Balancy face/slab to powerful overhanging moves which finishes off with a number of chicken heads to the chains.

Not sure how this route intended the climbing to go but I went WAYYYYYY right at the 3rd or 4th bolt. falling there would have not been fun. Some of these flakes seem thin. Tread lightly.

Also, if you know the name of this route and the FA, please update MP. Thanks!
content.protection: shiny newish bolts for your draws
content.location:
Every climb here says it's the first sport climb coming down into the area, climbers right. As of Nov 2020, this is the first sport climb after the descent into the area.

Start on top of a huge white slabby boulder climbers right of the cave and on the right side of the arete. stick clip one then boulder off the ground on big slopey holds.

content.description: Start about 8 ft. right of Holy Mackerel crack. climb the face up small ledges and crimps to a vertical crack. Make a long move to a good edge and finish up on the big belay ledge to a set of shared ring anchors for Holy Mackerel.
content.protection: Bring small TCUs or purple to red C3s to protect the crux. A bomber #1 C4 just below the crux will probably keep you off the deck if your gear pops, good pro returns after the difficulty. This route is best done on toprope after leading Holy Mackerel.
content.location: just to the right of the Holy Mackerel Crack

content.description: Climb the face with a mix of slab and a small roof to the anchors.
content.location: Start on the line of bolts just to the right of Wendy's Jugs.

climbs.name: Thunderdome
climbs.fa: Kurt Smith, Peilee Wren, Mark Pugeda 2020

content.description: Climb up and over a left facing flake, the anchors are right below a curved hemlock tree. This climb is really fun and worth doing.
content.location: The first fully bolted climb to the left of the Ice climb

content.description: Fire up the steep lower section to a crux just after the angle gives way. High feet and even a finger lock guard the rest of the tough section, after which you run it out through easier climbing to the top.
content.location: The sport route to the left of the huge corner that is Holy Mackerel.

climbs.name: Subdivisions
climbs.fa: Kurt Smith, Peilee Wren, Milo Smith 2020

content.description: Short route with a left facing corner at the top
content.location: To the right of Lil Boba

content.description: "Climbs a brainy face through a steep section." according to Williams' guidebook.
content.protection: 6 Bolts (The runout now has a bolt)
content.location: The sport route in the middle of the wall before you get to the popular "Aimee's Jugs"

content.description: The crux is right after the second bolt, the third bolt is currently missing the hanger, but can be protected with a C4 00. There is a committing move after the third bolt, followed by very fun climbing through a slightly overhung section and a two small roofs. Very fun route. If you are looking for a 12 in the area this is it!
content.protection: 6 bolts to bolt anchor, bring a 00 to protect bolts 2-3.
content.location: The route is on a long flat wall climbers left of "Jason and the Arguenuts" and right of a large roof with a boulder beneath it.

content.description: Angler route with nothing really difficult except for the one move overhang. One 10c move then gets pretty easy; bolted to this point. Extra bolts have been places that goes strait up from the hueco but its too easy, like ladder easy.
content.protection: Start at the left of the hueco; 4 bolts up keep on going left with a standard rack up to #2 cams and stoppers. Finish at same anchor as Crescent Corner. Alternate direct route goes 6 bolts straight up and I think it finishes at Cowboy Love anchor.

content.description: Trad climbers rejoice, you have a phenomonal finger lock crux from bolts 3-5. This climb is so good based on those cruxes alone!
content.location: Climbers right of SIN

climbs.name: Raw Milk
climbs.fa: DWS: Harrison Shull, Bolted: Rudaw Janowic, FFA: ?

content.description: Pumpy leftward traverse to a good rest, and then some tiny crimps at the crux.  Clipping the anchors can be tricky.
content.location: First bolted line left of Mojo Jojo Crack, easily visible as you trend climber's left from the walk-down approach.

content.description: This is the route which climbs a blunt arete of the buttress. Great moves in overhung part. Per guidebook 5.10b, but  today it felt as at least 5.10d.
content.location: North Whippoorwill. Left of "Bali".

content.description:
This route starts on the same wall as Blimey. Go past Jason and the Argonauts and cross the creek to find the vertical wall with 5 sport climbs.

Pondless is a sandbag and be ready for techy 11+ climbing. Strong fingers, high steps, and techy footwork will help you reach the anchors on this.

I talked to Rudaw about the grade on this route after i climbed it, not knowing the grade and guessing it to be around 11d/12a. He said 11b. It's funny because I mentioned to my friends (both strong climbers who were having trouble with the crux) that this would be 5.11- in some places in the country but it would be more consistent with 11c/d at the New. Rudaw is all over the place with his grading (perhaps he comes from a background where grades are way stiffer, maybe techy climbing is just that technical and not "that" hard, some of his routes clearly don't go direct through the bolt line and circumnavigate cruxes), but when you come across a good Rudaw route, you appreciate the job he has done opening new routes in our region.

Get on this thing (and all Rudaw routes) and be ready for anything regardless of the grade.
content.location: Just right of Blimey

content.description: Face climbing up the gray wall.
content.location:
First left of

Blimey.

content.description: Crux is probably clipping the 2nd bolt on thin feet and a crimpy sidepull. 4th bolt to anchors is a little stretched out but it is on easier climbing with a traverse right.
content.location: Second bolted line from the right as you come down the access trail to Whippoorwill.

content.description: Begin at the obvious crack near the ground just left of Bongo. Pull the roof and continue past the ledge to the face above. Gear in horizontals until you reach the the one bolt at the crux beneath the anchors. Most of the route is ~ 5.7 and the crux is bolted.
content.protection: Bolted anchors. One bolt at the crux before the anchors. Standard rack.
content.location: Come down Whippoorwill descent gulley and go right (climber's left). Past the roof is a set of 3 bolted juggy lines. Immediately to the left of them, there's an obvious crack near the ground capped by a small roof.

content.description: Crux near the top, otherwise really easy route.
content.location: Dihedral

content.description: Work up the dihedral created by the ledge to some high steps with good holds. Get into a section of underclings with a bigger move or two, and begin the search for the best hold from which to clip the anchors.
content.location: The route starts just left of the ledge in a corner. In between Kazuko, which starts on the ledge, and Bender.

content.description: Follow the broken crack to a horizontal break. Climb a tricky sequence on iron crimps and jugs, trending left to gain the shared anchor with wafer.
content.protection:
Single rack of cams to #2. Double up on #2 maybe.

Shared drop in shuts with Wafer.
content.location: One of the last routes on the approach trail before the beach. On the right side of the arête, next to Wafer.

content.description:
To find this new route (not in the second edition Mike Williams guide book), go way past Jason and the Argonauts, cross the creek, and find a huge roof with a cool boulder problem under. You'll find two bolted routes climber's left of the roof around the arete, the more left route being Morse Code.

This route climbs up vertical rock for ~50 feet. It starts to get steeper and bulbous for the last 35 feet. The beginning is fairly easy terrain starting out but be careful, the run outs are big and a fall in a few places would be epic.

As the route starts to get a bit steeper and makes its way through bulbous terrain and a few roofs, you'll enter the crux. Surmount the roof and be ready to stay on guard for the next few bolts until you reach the anchors. Long reaches and trusting slopey holds will get you to the chains.
content.location: Around the corner climbers left from Blimey. Just past the cool boulder problem and big cap roof.

content.description: Climb up a few big holds to a jug, slam some bomber small gear in the crack and fire the low crux on finger locks and good feet. Once established in the vertical crack, keep the pump at bay up ever easier terrain to the anchors.
content.protection: 00s to .75 camalot will sew it up.
content.location: The route sits under a roof just to the right (climber's left) of where the approach gully meets the rocky lake bed. The splitter bottom will give it away.

content.description: The crux is coming out of the roof at bolt 5 with some longer moves, from a side pull to crimp to side pull to crimp, then hop! This is a very fun route, it may be in your best interest to dog the first go to brush off the perpetual dirt through the first 2/3 bolts.
content.location: Climbers left of the entrance, about 100 yds left of a large roof with a boulder beneath it. This route stands directly in front of a large boulder.

content.description: This is a very high quality route. The first bolt is quite high (20 feet), consider stick clipping it. Start by climbing straight up passing the first bolt to reach the overhang. Pass the overhang on the left side following a flake. Diagonal up and right to reach a nice rest in a horizontal. From here, go straight up on some small and sloping holds aiming for a jug about 5 feet to the right of the next bolt (crux). From here, diagonal up and left to the finish, the climb gives you one more move to think about as you head to the shuts. This route is one of the first to get sun at this area.
content.protection: 6 bolts to a new 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: From the descent gully, head right (facing the lake).   Continue until you come to the obvious steep wall perpendicular to the lake with many sport routes.

content.description: Stick clip and climb the roof and face.  Underwater during the summer months.
content.location: The first route you come to, heading left at Whippoorwill.

climbs.name: Lil Boba
climbs.fa: Kurt Smith, Peilee Wren, Milo Smith 2020

content.description: Furthest left of the 4 bolted routes on a short wall. A few slabby moves down low and then pulling on good holds to the anchors.
content.location: First climb to the right of the ice climb

content.description: Sustained route with approximately 4 different 5.10a cruxes throughout.
content.location: Turn left after descending to Whippoorwill, walk past an arete to find the route which begins on a ledge next to an often wet bit of rock.

content.description: An overhanging jug haul that can be climbed year long on both ropes and DWS.
content.protection: 5 bolts and can take some gear in the beginning to gain the first bolt. Anchors at top.
content.location: Walk far climber's left and it's the last arête.

content.description: rightmost route.
content.location:
Rightmost wall on the wall to the right when coming down the access trail to Whippoorwill.

Right of Pat-Agonia. It's possible to traverse to the anchors of Pat-Agonia from the anchors

content.description: Start on a Large Boulder that is normally underwater. Below a big Roof.  Ascend the highly featured arete up to a ledge below the roof.  Then head right up a lichen corner to a Pine Tree.  Rap or Anchor from the pine tree
content.protection:
Trad Rack

Rap from Pine Tree Anchor
content.location: Same wall as Latch Key Kids, but walk right until you reach the corner.

content.description: Climb a corner to a ledge and then head up the corner slightly to the left.
content.location: Corner system to the left of the big roof on the corner.

content.description: Great little route for boulderers.  Stick clippin the first bolt is advisable, as the first moves are strong and the landing horrible.  All together there are some bad fall possibilities here, but the clipping stances are great, just don't pump out with and handful of slack, mid-clip.  The V4 crux at midheight is a great little boulder problem.
content.protection: 5 bolts and anchors - 2nd bolt hangar is currently present (3/11)
content.location: At Whipporwill, just to the right of Stop the Presses, Mr. Cater; 2 routes to the left of Masuka.

climbs.name: How Could Hell Be Any Worse?

content.description:
A must for the aspiring adventure slab climber!

Climb the low angle face sifting through the sea of lichen for anything to aid in your upward progression. Enjoy a few thought provoking moves at the top of the slab, then keep it together through the steeper section to the anchors.
content.location: The fourth bolt line on the large slab (Mormon Wall) that's just before The Lost World. To the right of Back to the Known, and left of American Dream.

content.description: The second line on the wall south to access gully.
Start at a right facing crack that angles right near the top that puts you on a nice belay ledge about 50  ft. up. The belay ledge at the top is an awesome ledge to take photos.
content.protection: Gear to 4 inches to a set of ring anchors on the ledge.
content.location: Obvious layback crack just left of flounder. Only accessible in the winter when the lake is drained.

content.description: Start by clipping the very low bolt while standing on a boulder.  Climb staight up the arete like feature to reach an overhang.  Awkward moves over the overhang will put you on a face with a crack with a few pods.  Climb the face to reach a large ledge and shuts.
content.location: This route can only be accessed during low water.  This is the next sport line to the left of Mojo Jojo Crack.  It's about 20 yards down the cliff from Wafer.

climbs.name: Godzilla and Little Foot
climbs.fa: Kurt Smith, Peilee Wren, Milo Smith 2020

content.description: Fun route that starts to the left of a thin crack and has some cool exposed moves onto a small arete at the top
content.location: Second from the right of the 4 bolted climbs on the short wall, right of Subdivisions

content.description: What a nice 5.9!   Start to the left of the high first bolt and climb up to reach a nice ledge and traverse right to make the first clip.   From here, head up and right to the 2nd bolt (crux).   It's nothing but jugs from here.   This route is every bit as good as the many moderates on Orange Oswald Wall.
content.protection: 7 bolts, with new bolted anchors with rap rings. At any point you could supplement the bolts with gear if you felt so inclined.
content.location: From the descent gully, continue right (facing the lake).   This climb is around the arete after passing Hat Change, 5.10d and Blaze Got a New Job, 5.11b.   Start is just to the left of a large boulder.

content.description: Thin face climbing on seemingly invisible holds.
The corner route right of Ching, Chang, Chong.
content.protection: A bunch of #1s. No top anchor.

content.description: A little bit of everything: finger crack, balancey arete moves, crimps, underclings. Sustained after 20ft up, the crux comes balancing the arete moves. Miles harder than Flounder but definitely more satifying.
content.location: The bolted route left of arete right of Flounder.

content.description: Start roughly 8 feet left of the route After Forever, which is immediately left of Wendy's Jugs.  Start on a juggy crack system and follow it to overhanging jugs.
content.protection: Cams to 3".  Stoppers useful.  Tricams useful but not necessary.  If no one's on After Forever you can use that bolted anchor.  If it's taken, top out and use a tree.

content.description: Climb the face just left of Masuko. There are some long reaches between pockets on this one. Some holds have broken, making this route a grade or two harder.

Another worthwhile Whippoorwill trad line. Climb up to the obvious corner. Make a mix of crack, stemming, and face moves to reach a good stance (crux). Move right to the face, and continue up the very cool horizontals to the anchor.
content.protection: Some small gear is useful for the start of the crack and the upper face. The upper face is slightly runout.
content.location: Obvious feature to the right of Latchkey Kids.

content.description: Direct route that starts on the left side of the hueco.
content.protection: Three bolts to a standard rack. Two bolts anchor.

content.description: Straightforward climbing with one tough move working out to the left brings you up to the roof. If you're thinking 'boy, this feels pretty easy for a 12 so far, these moves over the roof must be nails!' then you are correct. Grab the two good pockets, then figure out a sequence through the tiny and/or severely slopey holds above. Easy climbing to the top from there. Boulderers, this route is for you.
content.location: Bolt line between Latch Key Kids and Crescent Corner, easy enough to set up a TR from Latch Key Kids.

content.description: The crux is half way up.
content.protection: 8 bolts with anchors. Could be climbed with gear. New bolted anchors with rap rings.
content.location: Come down Whippoorwill descent gulley and go right. Past the roof is a set of 3 bolted juggy lines. This is the middle line of the 3.

content.description:
This is a very nice trad route and on a busy day might be one of the few routes without a line on it, a good reason to bring a rack down to whippoorwill.

Start in the corner near the cave, climb up the very enjoyable corner with some good moves. At the roof, traverse right to some very good holds out on the face. Finish up the face and crack, aiming for the bolted anchors.
content.protection:
Good mix of pro, a #4 can be helpful to protect the roof moves.

Bolted anchor at the top. When toproping this, be mindful of the rope getting stuck in the crack.
content.location: Obvious corner left of "Straight Outta Lockmont"

content.description: Fun route with big ol' cave up towards the top. Usually drys quickly after a rain.
content.protection: 7 Bolts with new bolted anchors with rap rings.
content.location: Come down Whippoorwill descent gulley and go right. Past the roof is a set of 3 bolted juggy lines. This is the furthest left of the 3.

content.description:
Go past Jason and the Argonauts and cross the talus field over the short creek until you hit the next vertical wall of sport climbs. This wall will be just right of a huge roof and a cool V2 boulder problem on a free standing boulder under the roof.

Blimey is the second most right route on the wall, just left of Pondless. This is a good warm up for the wall. Face climbing and route finding (if there is no chalk) will get you up this thing.
content.location: Just left of Pondless and the new unnamed route on the adjacent wall

content.description: This route has fairly continuous climbing, great rock quality, and nice moves.  The first bolt hanger is missing (originally 5 bolts) so you might want to stick clip.
content.location: Start a few feet to the left of Hat Change, 5.10d.

content.description:
A sustained fun climb on super solid white rock.

Climb up the easier terrain to the high first bolt. Continue up to the overhang where the business starts. Crimp hard and work to a jug and some easier moves to follow. Catch a much needed rest on the ledge and fire the last few moves on the increasingly slopier holds to a balancy finish.
content.location: In between Masuko and Nonameyet.

content.description: This route follows the obvious right-angling crack.
content.location:
North Whippoorwill, left of

Java

.

content.description: Follow thin crack/seam up the tall face.
content.location: On the Mormon Wall, which is a smooth slabby face right of the second tree island past Holy Mackerel area (maybe 100 yds) . Begins at thin seam that is right of the tree island. It would be the first climb with a start underwater if the water was up.

content.description: Follow a couple thin moves to much easier climbing above.  Crux is low on this one.
content.protection: 5 bolts, and a two bolt anchor.
content.location: Immediately left of Wendy's Jugs.

content.description: Climb straight up on in-cut jugs, clipping bolts along the way.  Several good rests and solid rock.
content.location: From the approach trail, head left at the base of the wall and continue until you are thirty feet or so from the large arete.

content.description: Crux is at the first two bolts.  All the holds are there, you just have to find them.  Once you surmount the ledge, the climbing eases significantly, which is the hallmark trait of pretty much this entire wall.
content.protection: 7 bolts and a 2 bolt anchor with rings at the top.
content.location: Immediately right of the crag favorite Aimee's Jugs.
